text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
Section 11071 of Public Law 115-97, 131 Stat. 2054 (Dec. 22, 2017), extended the time in which a third party could administratively and judicially contest an IRS levy from nine months to two years.
(1) CCDM 34.5.3 is revised to reﬂect the amendment to Code section 6532(c) that changed the period of limitation on suits by third parties from nine months to two years.
This section supersedes CCDM 34.5.3 dated 08-11-2004.

) This section covers the types of civil actions that may be brought against the United States by persons other than taxpayers under section
) Section

) authorizes a suit directly against the United States by a third person claiming that the Government wrongfully levied upon such person’s property to satisfy the tax liability of another. Wrongful, as used in section, refers to a proceeding against property that is not the taxpayer’s. In general, if a levy has been made on property, or property has been sold pursuant to a levy, any person other than the taxpayer who claims an in or lien on such property, may bring a civil action against the United (
) An action under section

may be brought without regard to whether the property has been surrendered to or sold by the Service. A third person may not bring a wrongful levy action before the Service has in fact levied upon property. (
) The remedies provided by section
are the exclusive means of redress actions that may be brought under this section. A third party may not bring a
U.S.C §
quiet title action, which may have a longer (six-year) period of limitation, to recover wrongfully levied property. (
) The injunctive relief afforded by section
) is available: • Only in wrongful levy actions brought under section

); • Only after the property has in fact been levied upon by the Service; • Only if the court determines that the levy has been wrongful • If the levy or a sale of property pursuant to the levy would irreparably injure the rights of a third party in such property; and • If the court determines that the rights of such third party in such property are superior to the rights of the United States. (

) If the court’s determination is in favor of the third party, typically the is either made permanent (if, for example, the property was not yet surren- dered to the Service) or is continued until the levy is released and the property is returned to the third person. (
) If the court determines the Service’s levy is wrongful, the court may under section

): • Order the return of speciﬁc property if the property is identiﬁable and United States is in possession of such property. • Grant a judgment for the amount of money levied upon. • Grant a judgment for an amount not exceeding the amount received the Service from the sale of such property, or the fair market value of such property immediately before the levy. (
) Where a third party recovers a money judgment, interest at the rate set by section

is allowed from the date the Service received the money fully levied upon to the date of payment of such judgment. Money wrongfully levied upon is “received” at the time the Government acquired possession of such money. Chief Counsel Directives Manual

Suits Brought Against the United (
) Section

(h) authorizes the payment of actual, economic damages by a third party in a wrongful levy suit if there is a ﬁnding that an officer or employee recklessly, intentionally, or negligently disregarded a provision of Code. The third party must exhaust administrative remedies under the same rules set forth in section
) Section

) provides that if surplus proceeds have been realized from the sale of property by the United States pursuant to a levy, any person — than the taxpayer) who claims an interest in or lien upon such property junior to the lien or interest of the United States, and claims to be legally entitled to all or part of such surplus proceeds, may bring an action against the United States in a district court of the United States. (

) “Surplus proceeds” are those in excess of the amount necessary to satisfy tax liability giving rise to the levy and the expenses of the levy sale. Once a taxpayer’s liability is satisﬁed, the Government’s retention of surplus is wrongful as to the person legally entitled to them. (
) Section
) provides that if the court determines that the interest or of any party to an action under section

was transferred to the proceeds of sale or property sold pursuant to a levy, the court may grant a judgment against the United States in an amount equal to all or any part of the amount of the surplus proceeds of such sale. The relief available under this section may be granted only in cases brought under section
) Section
) was enacted to provide that if property has been sold pursuant to an agreement described in section

), any person (including the taxpayer) who claims to be legally entitled to all or any part of the amount held as a fund pursuant to such agreement, may join the ment in a civil action to assert a claim to those proceeds. (
) Section

(b) permits the issuance of a certiﬁcate of discharge where property subject to a tax lien is sold and, under an agreement with the the proceeds from the sale are held as a fund subject to the liens and claims of the United States in the same manner, and with the same priority, as the liens and claims on the discharged property. This provision was instituted to aid in the disposition of property where a dispute exists among competing lienors, including the United States, concerning their rights to speciﬁc (
) Any person including the taxpayer may bring an action under this provision whether or not such person was a party to the agreement described in
) Section

) provides that if the court determines that a party has an interest in or a lien upon an amount held as a fund pursuant to an providing for the proceeds of sale of property to be substituted for the the court may grant a judgment in an amount not in excess of the substituted sale proceeds.

) The following covers the miscellaneous procedural matters related to civil actions brought against the United States by persons other than taxpayers. (
) Section
(c) provides that, for purposes of an adjudication under section

, the assessment of tax upon which the interest or lien of the United of Assessment States is based shall be conclusively presumed to be valid. Thus, the the tax liability are not contestable unless the United States asks for foreclosure of its lien in such actions. (
) Section
(c) provides a period of limitation on suits by persons other taxpayers. Generally, except as provided in section
), no suit or of Limitations on ceeding under section
shall begin after two years from the date of the levy or agreement giving rise to such action. (
) If a third party makes an administrative request under section
(b) for return of property that has been wrongfully levied, then the
-year period of limitation on suits may be extended. It is extended (but not abridged) until whichever of the following two dates occurs soonest: (
) the date that is
months from the date on which the third party ﬁled the section
(b) istrative request; or (
) the date that is
months from the date on which Service mailed a notice of disallowance of such request by registered or certiﬁed mail. (
) Section

(d) provides for a limitation on rights of action in that no action may be maintained against any officer or employee of the United States (or States as former officer or employee) or his/her personal representative with respect any action that could be maintained under section

If an action that be brought against the United States under this section is improperly against one of the aforementioned individuals, the pleadings may be to substitute the United States as a party-defendant for such individual, as the time such action was commenced, upon proper service of process on United States. ) Section
(f) provides that the provisions of section
(a) (relating to hibition of suit prior to ﬁling claim for refund) shall not apply to actions Claims section
It is, therefore, unnecessary for a person to ﬁle an Not Required claim for a refund before instituting an action under section

Brought Against the United States 34.5.3
If a certiﬁcate of discharge is issued to any person under section
) with respect to any property, such person may, within

days after the day on which such certiﬁcate is issued, bring a civil action against the United States for a determination of whether the value of the interest of the United States (if any) in such property is less than the value determined by the Service. No other action may be brought by such person for such a determina- tion.
The following covers the miscellaneous procedural matters related to civil actions brought against the United States by persons other than taxpayers.
Section

(d) provides for a limitation on rights of action in that no action may be maintained against any officer or employee of the United States (or former officer or employee) or his/her personal representative with respect to any action that could be maintained under section

If an action that could be brought against the United States under this section is improperly brought against one of the aforementioned individuals, the pleadings may be amended to substitute the United States as a party-defendant for such individual, as of the time such action was commenced, upon proper service of process on the United States. ) Similarly, the ﬁling of an administrative application under section
(b) (relating to surplus proceeds), seeking a distribution of surplus proceeds resulting from a sale of property pursuant to levy, is not a prerequisite to commencement of an action under section

) This is in contrast to a ﬁnding of liability for damages under section third party may not recover a liability for actual, direct economic damages above or beyond the damages suffered by the wrongful levy or other adjudicated under section
(b) unless such third party ﬁrst timely all administrative remedies as would be appliable under section

) On occasion the taxpayer will initiate a proceeding in the federal district to perpetuate the testimony of some witness believed to be relevant and material to a potential tax case. The appropriate Civil Trial Section of the Division handles these cases, and they are handled as suits brought the United States and opened as collection cases in the Office of Chief Counsel. (

) Upon receipt of information that such a case has been commenced, should assemble all facts and ﬁles and then prepare a letter addressed to Tax Division, Attn: Civil Trial Section, Such letter should be in the form of a defense letter and contain a dation as to whether the petition should be opposed. The letter will be on behalf of Chief Counsel in the ﬁeld office and forwarded to the Tax (
) All facts and ﬁles will be made available to the Tax Division lawyer the case. (

) Because the results of the case and any related papers could be pertinent any future Tax Court case or refund suit, special efforts should be made to associate the immediate information with any Service ﬁles for future use. (
) The above procedures apply only if there is no suit already commenced by taxpayer.
34.5 Suits Brought Against the United States
